    A one-dimensional harmonic oscillator has Hamiltonian

    H=12mp^2+12mω2x^2=ℏω(a†a+12),H=\frac{1}{2 m} \hat{p}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} \hat{x}^{2}=\hbar \omega\left(a^{\dagger} a+\frac{1}{2}\right), H=2m1​p^​2+21​mω2x^2=ℏω(a†a+21​),

    where

    a=(mω2ℏ)1/2(x^+imωp^),a†=(mω2ℏ)1/2(x^−imωp^) obey [a,a†]=1a=\left(\frac{m \omega}{2 \hbar}\right)^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{x}+\frac{i}{m \omega} \hat{p}\right), \quad a^{\dagger}=\left(\frac{m \omega}{2 \hbar}\right)^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{x}-\frac{i}{m \omega} \hat{p}\right) \quad \text { obey } \quad\left[a, a^{\dagger}\right]=1 a=(2ℏmω​)1/2(x^+mωi​p^​),a†=(2ℏmω​)1/2(x^−mωi​p^​) obey [a,a†]=1

    Assuming the existence of a normalised state ∣0⟩|0\rangle∣0⟩ with a∣0⟩=0a|0\rangle=0a∣0⟩=0, verify that

    ∣n⟩=1n!a†n∣0⟩,n=0,1,2,…|n\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{n !}} a^{\dagger n}|0\rangle, \quad n=0,1,2, \ldots ∣n⟩=n!​1​a†n∣0⟩,n=0,1,2,…

    are eigenstates of HHH with energies EnE_{n}En​, to be determined, and that these states all have unit norm.

    The Hamiltonian is now modified by a term

    λV=λℏω(ar+a†r)\lambda V=\lambda \hbar \omega\left(a^{r}+a^{\dagger r}\right) λV=λℏω(ar+a†r)

    where rrr is a positive integer. Use perturbation theory to find the change in the lowest energy level to order λ2\lambda^{2}λ2 for any rrr. [You may quote any standard formula you need.]

    Compute by perturbation theory, again to order λ2\lambda^{2}λ2, the change in the first excited energy level when r=1r=1r=1. Show that in this special case, r=1r=1r=1, the exact change in all energy levels as a result of the perturbation is −λ2ℏω-\lambda^{2} \hbar \omega−λ2ℏω.

    The components of σ=(σ1,σ2,σ3)\boldsymbol{\sigma}=\left(\sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2}, \sigma_{3}\right)σ=(σ1​,σ2​,σ3​) are 2×22 \times 22×2 hermitian matrices obeying

    for any unit vector n\mathbf{n}n. Show that these properties imply

    (a⋅σ)(b⋅σ)=a⋅b+i(a×b)⋅σ(\mathbf{a} \cdot \boldsymbol{\sigma})(\mathbf{b} \cdot \boldsymbol{\sigma})=\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}+i(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \cdot \boldsymbol{\sigma} (a⋅σ)(b⋅σ)=a⋅b+i(a×b)⋅σ

    for any constant vectors a and b\mathbf{b}b. Assuming that θ\thetaθ is real, explain why the matrix U=exp⁡(−in⋅σθ/2)U=\exp (-i \mathbf{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{\sigma} \theta / 2)U=exp(−in⋅σθ/2) is unitary, and show that

    U=cos⁡(θ/2)−in⋅σsin⁡(θ/2)U=\cos (\theta / 2)-i \mathbf{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{\sigma} \sin (\theta / 2) U=cos(θ/2)−in⋅σsin(θ/2)

    Um⋅σU−1=m⋅σcos⁡θ+(n×m)⋅σsin⁡θU \mathbf{m} \cdot \boldsymbol{\sigma} U^{-1}=\mathbf{m} \cdot \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cos \theta+(\mathbf{n} \times \mathbf{m}) \cdot \boldsymbol{\sigma} \sin \theta Um⋅σU−1=m⋅σcosθ+(n×m)⋅σsinθ

    where m\mathbf{m}m is any unit vector orthogonal to n\mathbf{n}n.

    The Hamiltonian for a particle of spin 12\frac{1}{2}21​ in a magnetic field B\mathbf{B}B is

    H=−12ℏγB⋅σ where σx=(0110),σy=(0−ii0),σz=(100−1)H=-\frac{1}{2} \hbar \gamma \mathbf{B} \cdot \boldsymbol{\sigma} \quad \text { where } \quad \sigma_{x}=\left(\begin{array}{cc} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{array}\right), \quad \sigma_{y}=\left(\begin{array}{cc} 0 & -i \\ i & 0 \end{array}\right), \quad \sigma_{z}=\left(\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{array}\right)H=−21​ℏγB⋅σ where σx​=(01​10​),σy​=(0i​−i0​),σz​=(10​0−1​)

    and γ\gammaγ is a constant (the motion of the particle in space can be ignored). Consider a magnetic field which is independent of time.
